moves.1. d3: I'm black here and open with Fisher/Reti.  It sets up an early queenside attack, a blunder by white, and an early 3 point advantage.  Due to sheer stupidity, I lose a big advantage and am forced to accept a stalemate in the end.  Lesson learned, don't get overly confident.
Black sets a trap, and white misses it.
moves.11. bxc4 Rxb2: At this point, smart, conservative play would be in order.  Instead, I get overly confident and give up a big lead.
moves.12. Rb1 Rxb1 13. Qxb1 Qa5:
At this point, I was hoping for a chance to pressure his queen.
14. Qa1 Nh5
15. Qa2 Nb4
16. Qb3 Nc6
moves.21... Bxg4 22. f3 Bf5 23. d4 cxd4 24. ex: How could I mess this up?  :-)
moves.25... Nf4 26. Rb1 O-O 27. Rb7 e5: This is sloppy play by me (black) here.
moves.28. Nxd6 Nxg2:
29. Kxg2 Bc8
30. Nxc8 Rxc8
31. Rb4 Bc3
moves.29. Nxf5 gxf5 30. Kxg2 Rc8 31. Rd7 Rxc4: 40. Kxe5 Rxf3 41. Rc8  Kg7 42. Ra8 Re3
moves.40. Kxe5 Rxf3 41. Rc6: Another very sloppy play by black (me).
moves.41... a5 42. Rxh6 Kg7 43. Ra6 Ra3 44. Kf:
During the game, I take notes on what I expect.  In this case (it's rare), I predicted this series accurately.
46. Rxa5 f6 
47. Kf5 Rf3 
48. Ke4 Rh3
White brilliantly recognizes the stalemate possibilities and expertly forces one.

gameName: It never hurts to play for a stalemate
